title: Will there be a new prime minister of Italy before 24 January 2021?
preds: The timeline is too close unless he abdicates

Conte could retain enough support when economic & health stability appear to be a possibility. 
Upending the current administration & developing new seems to be overreaching with the immediate concerns of society.

He survived a No Confidence vote recently:
https://www.dw.com/en/italian-pm-giuseppe-conte-survives-confidence-vote-in-senate/a-56277943

Because:
- there are only a few days left before January 24th, 
- it has not happened or is not announced in the media, 
- there has been a consensus for several days from other foreasters
Current pandemic and raising numbers of cases tend to shift the focus off political issues
@SE_Meyer  Conte's time is limited, it seems - https://reut.rs/36in863 - however, I see no reason for him to resign from his current position in the next 3 days.

One has to come back to 1979 to see a PM surviving a third general election. Conte will be judged on his handling of the Covid Crisis which has left a scar on the country. It's hard to see him getting renewed by a coalition. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Italy
Conte just survived a confidence vote

Two confidence votes done. It would not take opposition parties to ask the president to ask him to resign. This seems extremely unlikely before the 24th January and in the wake of the confidence votes. Nevertheless, this is Italy.

Not many are happy with the prospect of early elections, especially the M5S and Forza Italia (Berlusconi, who is very old and sick right now), and in my view, even Mr. Salvini lost a lot of his appeal lately, especially with his imprudent support of the latest Trump’s braveries. Moreover, it was recently decided—via referendum—that in the next elections the elected deputies (Representatives) will go from 630 to 400 and senators from 315 to 200. It means that a good part of the current parliamentarians will not be there in the next legislature. Yesterday news said that there was a "warming up" between Conte and Renzi, and this morning some even said that Renzi is trying to blame his two Ministers (how nice). Probably it did occured to him that he won't go anywhere. To go back to the question, if Conte resigns the President may call for a technocratic government (Cottarelli comes to mind), because the thing that creates the real commotion is the handling of the Funds from the EU. 
If there will be a technocratic governement then it can be fast, but the 24 is too fast! 
If there is a call to early vote, than the 24 is out of the question.
Highly unlikely considering no announcement of a pending election to the office of prime minister.

Turmoil in Italian politics has erupted in the last few weeks, driven by a previous Prime Minister, Matteo Renzi - https://abcn.ws/3oXGpkk. However, it is worth recognising that Renzi's current poll ratings are lower than when he formed his Italia Viva party a couple of years ago. So an election in the short term is unlikely to benefit him or his party. That being the scenario, what is his likely motive for removing his two ministers from the coalition and leaving Conte without a majority? More influence in the current coalition is the most likely answer. Particularly with the regard to the allocation and distribution of EU Covid recovery funds. See https://bit.ly/2Kn1MMS and https://reut.rs/3in3rPh. M5S and PD, the other two coalition parties are also not likely to benefit from a short term election. The most likely gainer from a short term election would be the right wing with Salvini, Brothers of Italy and Forza Italia. Adding to the minimal chances of a short term election has been the call by the President of the country, Sergio Mattarella, to put country  before politics in the face of the current coronavirus crisis. Thus, in spite of the current turmoil in Italian politics, it is unlikely Conte will be out of office in a matter of 7 days albeit he may lose the 'vote of confidence' in the parliament and senate this coming week.

This is an impossible Italian scenario. I will assume that Conte will be there until January 2021 when there is legislation to review State of alarm until 30th January. But as it is Italy _Who knows? https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jan/13/italy-facing-fresh-elections-after-ex-pm-withdraws-party-from-coalition  https://www.dw.com/en/italy-prime-minister-giuseppe-conte-loses-senate-majority/a-56216694 https://www.politico.eu/article/italy-government-crisis-reshuffle-giuseppe-conte-matteo-renzi-salvini-luigi-di-maio/ https://www.gov.uk/government/news/pm-call-with-prime-minister-giuseppe-conte-14-january-2021 https://www.thelocal.it/20210113/italian-ministers-quit-sparking-government-crisis https://www.thelocal.it/20210114/italy-to-extend-covid-19-state-of-emergency-until-april-30th
Italy has had 58 prime ministers. Conte currently ranks in the top 20 for longevity.

GZero Newsletter: Following the collapse Wednesday of Italy's government, all eyes are now on Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte's next move. Conte can try to cobble together another coalition by giving more power to the center-left Viva Italia party, but that would be perceived as caving to the demands of a junior coalition partner that caused the current crisis because it wants to dole out more on pandemic economic relief — a move Conte rebuffed because he says it will plunge Italy further into massive debt. Conte could also seek a confidence vote in parliament and hope the far-left Five Star platform whips up more votes in favor than against. Or he could give up and ask to call an election, with the far-right Lega party ahead in national polls and poised to win a majority with its allies. The government collapse comes at a perilous moment for Italy, which is battling a surge in COVID cases after being one of the hardest-hit countries in the world back in the spring. With the economy in dire straits, more political instability is the last thing the country needs, but Conte — a technocrat appointed to his position as a compromise between the populist right and left, with no political base of his own — may be powerless to stop it.

Next Monday Jan 18 Primer Miniser Giuseppe Conte will report to the House on the crisis and on Tuesday to the Senate. Then there would be voting. This means that he will try to avoid his removal. In the Chamber of Deputies he would have no problem gaining trust. He would win the vote even without or against the votes of Italia Viva. The problem is in the Senate, but an attempt is being made to form a group to replace the 18 senators from Italia Viva. Both the PD and M5E have already said that they do not want Renzi (leader of Italia Viva) because "he is not to be trusted."
Reports say that most party leaders will not push for elections in the middle of a crisis.  More than 70% of Italians, according to polls, do not want early voting. 
Its less likely that Italia Viva will achieve his removal, from a minority.
too little time for all required procedures to take place until 24th
The choices of economic stimulus will be too broad and force a new coalition

Although the country is indeed in a crisis it is highly likely that the current PM will stay in by this deadline. Italy will probably get a new PM before their next election in 2023 so not guaranteed that it won't change in the next 9 days

Italian politicians break out in a rash if there hasn't been a new government for a while, so I suppose I should have expected this.  Odds are they won't get a new one by the 24th, but I've come up from zero in recognition of that allergy.
The process be long, and Hampered by corona
The due date is too soon

Ten days to go. May be close. From the Economist 
“Matteo Renzi, Italy’s former prime minister, pulled his support from the country’s ruling coalition, faulting the government’s erratic response to the pandemic. Three ministers belonging to Mr Renzi’s small Italia Viva party resigned from Giuseppe Conte’s cabinet. It is not yet clear whether or how the prime minister will survive in office.“
Revising back down again after I panicked a bit from reading some Italian news suggesting he was gone. Looks like he'll remain in place for now.
Too little time remaining for anything substantial on this front now
Italy doesn’t want an exchange of power during a crisis
My first forecast, thus the late forecast.  With only a handful of days left and the middle of a pandemic, an unscheduled election before 24 January seems unlikely.
Conte is fairly popular and with Covid-19 still a major emergency, a new PM seems not so likely
Internal coalition turmoil but Conte seems to think he can stay put for now.

@Wildwood2000  The Italian Parliament today passed the 2021 budget - https://reut.rs/3hsk1wu - in spite of a) some tensions in the ruling coalition and b) a tight timeline that limited debate. This, combined with what many perceive as Conte's success in dealing with the EU and the EU covid recovery program funding, is for the time being, ensuring Conte's continued position as Prime Minister. Considering the holiday period and the continuing increase in Coronavirus cases in both Italy and EU, IMO this is unlikely to change in the next 25 days.

FYI from Economist 
“Italy’s prime minister, Giuseppe Conte, looked embattled as he addressed the Italian parliament this morning. He was seeking the backing of lawmakers for a reform of the EU’s bailout fund, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). The reform, due for approval at a euro zone leaders’ meeting on December 11th, has engendered deep misgivings in the Five Star Movement (M5S), a partner in Mr Conte’s coalition. But a last-minute compromise was reached on the wording of the government’s motion and, with the M5S lagging in the polls, few of its parliamentarians are expected to rebel. Now, however, Italia Viva, a group led by Matteo Renzi, a former prime minister, is threatening to mutiny over plans for a special task force to oversee the spending of the bonanza Italy expects from the EU’s post-pandemic recovery fund. Asked if the government could fall, Mr Renzi said he hoped not, but feared it would.“

Italy has had 28 changes in the holder of the office of Prime Minister since 1946. This gives an arrival rate of 28/74 per year = %37.4 per year, or roughly %0.1 per day. Adjusting for the 52 days remaining gives a base rate of %5.2 that there will be a new Prime Minister. I adjust this down to %3 in light of strong approval for Conte in the electorate, with a view towards the fact that some of his mid-year popularity seems to have waned in the recent months.

Nothing on the horizon to suggest Conte will not still be in office on 24 Jan 2021. Italy formally begins the G20 Presidency today. Conte's stature, both in EU, G20 and at home appear to be on the ascendency. Conte has brought a mood of calm to Italian politics unseen for many years. His management of the Covid-19 pandemic has largely been considered good by most Italians which has also strengthened his position in the coalition. See https://bit.ly/33DGqRJ.

Absolutely not. Living in Italy and speaking with political experts here I can tell you that Conte government will in all real likely-hood continue through '22 even if it is viewed as a weak coalition. PM distance from nationalizing issues present during regional elections 3/3 +Vd'Aos gives remaining win to SQ. + short of a series of bad decisions related to inability to set goals/plans//and//spend ESM next gen funds reduces the dissolve possibility to very low. Not impossible just much much lower than I initially went for. At this point experts agree that there's no reason to dissolve the parl. and have NE through '22 which means new PM '23.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Italy#Italian_Republic_(1946-present)   Conte became PM on 1/06/2018, if he remains PM until 24/01/2021 it would have been for 2 years and 239 days. Only 3/14 PM's have exceeded this length of time ->
Conte goes before 24/1/2021 = 79% = (14 - 3) /14 However given 8 months have past since on this 12 month long question when it was first asked and he remains PM, I will adjust ->
Conte goes before 24/1/2021 = 26% = 79% * (12 - 8) / 12

Updated 20201006 Conte is to request parliament to extend the country's COVID-19 State of Emergency to the end of January 20210 - https://reut.rs/33yDZQR. Conte continues to he well regarded by Italians - https://bit.ly/2SzOXPW - and this combined with the approval of a significant injection of EU funds into the economy, should the EU approve the Covid recovery funding, and the extension of the State of Emergency all continue to cement Conte's position as PM. As of 20200921, the regional elections and referendum on reducing the number of seats in Parliament from 945 to 600 and from 315 to 200 in the senate appear to have strengthened Giuseppe Conte's position. Additionally, his success in obtaining  €209bn in funding from the EU will add to his credibility. The mostly likely risk remaining risk to his position is from internal squabbling in the coalition of centrist and left parties currently governing Italy.  As the referendum has effectively approved the reduction of seats in the parliament, it will take some time for the required legislation to be processed and enacted. It will also take time for the new electoral boundaries to to be created and enacted. The likelihood of that being completed prior to 24 January 2021 is at best remote. Thus, Conte's position looks secure for the time being and hence my revised forecast.

In any case, it is too late now to vote (and COVID doesn't make things any easier), and then before they will agree on a coalition and a new PM it will be well after January!

44% is what I calculated as the base rate since 1948 (current republic): 43 PMs in 72 years means 5% chance of new PMs per month. Means 44% given 8.8 months left.  Apart from that I do not tilt in either direction: On the one hand, there is likely to be much upheaval given the impact of Covid19 on the economy. But on the other hand the system seems relatively stable at the moment, with no one but the current government being able to form a new majority coalition at current polls. PD would need to be able to seriously benefit from a new government or there would have to be a political crisis. However, any "planned" government upheaval by PD will likely be silently postponed until crisis is under control. Looking out for indicators in that direction.
Great guy, but a heck of an economic mess to clean up in a short time.

It doesn't seem like he'll stop being prime minister due to COVID-19 in the near future, however, the dramatic consequences on the economy may see him removed later in the year [1]. [1] https://theconversation.com/coronavirus-lessons-from-italy-on-the-difficulties-of-exiting-lockdown-137195

Giuseppe Conte has had a bad second half of April. You could say it all began on the 10th of April when he publicly accused opposition leaders Matteo Salvini and Giorgia Meloni of being liars. These accusations were met with responses comparing Conte's actions with that of a regime. However criticism of the Prime Minister is focused on a series of aspects, the most important being the economical policies adopted by the government to combat the effects of COVID-19. It has been approximately a month since most business in Italy had to close. The vast majority of these businesses were not prepared for this long of a closure and are now facing serious financial difficulties. Along with this unemployment rose to 11.6% in April from 9.8% at the end of 2019. Most of the economical tactics employed by Conte have been ineffective, they usually consisted of going on live TV and promising Italian citizens sums of money which never arrived. Conte also stated that Italy did not need to resort to the use of the European Stability Mechanism and then one week later an agreement was reached with the EU that allowed for the possibility of the ESM to be used. Now this was all done without taking into consideration what was thought of the ESM in Parliament, Conte was heavily criticized for not considering what opposition leaders had to say and above all what his own party had to say. Yes, Conte's very own political party was unsure of what to do regarding the ESM. Along with these mishaps are a serious of smaller actions which I won't describe.
Now, given this context, I believe that if an election will be held it will be held on the grounds that Conte was unable to successfully protect the Italian economy. However, the coalition of left wing parties holds the majority and I see it unlikely that they will be willing to risk going to the polls. If the coalition is to break it will be precisely because of this economic tension within the government. It also has to be said that the leaders of the main EU countries see Conte's exit as Prime Minister as a threat. I believe that Italian citizens are just now starting to realize how inefficient the EU is and how one-sided it has become. This new vision, which will most likely be adopted by the next Prime Minister, threaten the stability of the EU as Italy is a large contributor of funds. Conte would be pressured by Macron and Merkel to stay because they fear that someone like Matteo Salvini would succeed him. This would mean one of two things: Italy's exit from the EU or serious renegotiation.
Raising some. There will be a coronavirus reckoning. The question is where does Conti come out on that.

Outside view:
- Italy have had 10 PM's in the past 20 years = average tenure of 2 years per PM
- Conte will be there 2 years in July so he'll be doing better than average if he lasts tIll January next year. 
- Next election isn't until 2023. Basically the assumptions from @Ewell_Gregoor (hat tip) which I've verified. However, I interpret them slightly differently (think they balance out) so I'm at 50% pre-the inside view. Inside view:
- M5S still losing ground in the polls so unlikely to want another election. 
- PD's nowhere near strong enough to form a coalition with somebody outside of M5S
- Conte quite popular given handling of Corona crisis
- No election likely while emergency Coronavirus situation persists (3-4 months?)
- If there were an election tomorrow most likely scenario is Salvini gets in with support from Brothers of Italy (and probably Forza Italia too) Brings my probability down to 35%. Could arguably put it lower but 10 months is a long time (particularly in Italian politics!)

I first made this prediction before it was asked online. I will walk through my thinking since then. Based on government turnover in Italy since electoral reform (it was even more frequent before then): 45%. But that would be for any new government, even with Conte reappointed. Don't see him being a third term technocrat. If his gov't falls, it will because another person wants the Premiership. Lower the original 45% to 35%. Then, new information: Di Maio leaves the government, looking like he is positioning himself for an election. M5S lost ground in recent elections, making the coalition even smaller.

My views are as @Tetbury, @Yannick-M-hlh-user1574894083, and @schier1
It is not in the interest of the present coalition to call for early elections; 
M5S would lose big times--and they know it very well. 
PD also is very well aware of its weaknesses.
Conte performed surprisingly well. He was a perfect stranger, but he grew into his position and he is very well-liked. He didn't state any affiliation right now. He might eventually.
Salvini is the unruly one dreaming of the big chair, however, he is showing poor judgment, and quite frankly a lot of stupidity. His tenure as Minister of Internal Affair was quite inadequate.

I share Tetbury's reasoning. Doesn't seem in the interest of any of the big governing parties to produce a general election. They could change PM (unlikely imo, but we don't know what will happen this year (scandals, infighting)) or Five Stars could break apart. Also the base rate tells us that Italian PMs don't last long and Conte has been in office for over 1.5 years already.
Key is that any call for an early election would probably result in a bond sell off. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/27/italys-m5s-annihilated-in-regional-vote-which-pressures-fragile-government.html

Taking account of @schier1 two comments; the average Italian PM lasts about 2 years in the job and yesterdays regional elections seem to show that the Democratic Party (PD) has not collapsed and the League has not triumphed. But the M5S has done very poorly.  However nationally, the League and its allies (Lega  32%, FI 8%, FdI 11%) are a lot more popular than the PD (19%) and M5S (15.%). So this does not look too stable. M5S has performed worse in the Regional elections than its polling numbers suggested it would and it is being reported that M5S is having trouble with keeping     its MPs in line. A fractured M5S in the next few months could lead to the government falling. The government has a majority of 30 so if 16 MPs switched  away from the government presumably it would fall. The government coalition contains several very small parties that by themselves could not trigger an election by withdrawing from the government so a GE could only be triggered by the PD or M5S calling one or breaking up. If a GE occurred tomorrow the M5S would lose many seats and the PD would probably lose seats, so if a change to the PM does occur its likely to be due to the coalition deciding to change PM or the M5S breaking up. If the coalition tries to change the PM its likely that the coalition would break up. So my conclusion is that none of the government parties or MPs is likely to gain from either changing the PM or calling a GE, but the breakup of the M5S could accidentally cause a GE.

Last night, Salvini's party lost the regional elections in Emilia Romana, which was seen as a big test for the current government. Democrat candidate Bonaccini won 51,4% of the vote vs 43.8% for Borgonzoni (Salvini's candidate). This is a huge support for the current government and reduces political risk. Italian Government bonds are rallying this morning with the yield on the 10yr BTP falling bij 18bp.  Reducing probability...

Over the past decades prime ministers have served on average 2 years. Conti started on june 1st 2018 with his first coalition, then september 5th 2019 with the current coalition. There is always plenty of turmoil in Italian politics and now is no different. But given the breakdown of 5 star and the comeback of Democratic Party both have every incentive to hold on to this coalition and avoid early elections. For a new prime minister to be sworn in one needs to take into account the time to form a coalition (usually many months), the time to call new elections (including long summer break) which means for this event to happen snap elections need be called before june. Hence my below consensus forecast.

There needs to be an election, and they need to be able to form a government. In 2018, it took them 3 months to form a government. I think an election is pretty good, given the current environment. But, the risky part of that question is whether that will result in a governing coalition. League and Brothers have a good chance, but I'm going to hedge bets until an election is called and the poll numbers become relevant.

The base rate for Italian PMs is roughly 1 every 2 years since 1945, and Conte become PM in June 2018. There are a number of scenarios including a potential early Italian general election this year in which Conte could lose his position, the first of which is the Emilia Romagna regional elections where the League led by Salvini could win, the first time any other party has won in the region since 1945. Conte is not a member of a party, and if the distribution of the parties changes in parliament he does not have a party to back him.

In Italy, every time a bell rings they get a new prime minister :)

Italy has had PMs like Imelda Marcos has had shoes.   Almost nothing is going well enough for the current incumbent to predict survival into next year.
